CatDescriptText: Cutline of image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, August 8, 1953, pg. 20 reads: "At 'Old Folks Picnic' - When 100 aged persons held their annual picnic at Highland Park last Tuesday, these were some of the scenes...At the bottom left are shown, front row, Mrs. Dolly Johnson, Mrs. Mattie Davis, Mrs. Minnie Campbell, Mrs. Anna Watts, Mrs. Abraham Lincoln and Mrs. Anna Craig. Back row: Mrs. Louise Williams, Mrs. Alice Bollar, James Hughes, Mrs. Betty Evans and Mrs. Cornelia Twyman..."Article reads: "Aged Persons Enjoy Selves At Annual 'Old Folks Picnic' - The one-tenth of the American population which has reached the age of 60 and are still going strong are doing their part to make their lives as happy as possible.  In many communities, including Pittsburgh, they have their own annual social events and picnic to which they look forward each year.  Pittsburgh's annual 'Old Folks' Picnic' is such an event and needless to say the elderly people have a 'gay old time.'  On Tuesday, Aug. 4, 100 older persons composed of aged and shut-in members of Ebenezer Church, residents of the Lemington Avenue Home for Aged Women, and residents of the Aged Ministers' and Laymen's Home on Oakwood Street, journeyed again to the Farm House in Highland Park for their annual picnic.  The guests were picked up and brought to the park and retuned to their homes.  The annual 'Old Folks' Picnic' is sponsored by the James East Mission Society of the Ebenezer Baptist Church.  Mrs. Georgianna Fitzgerald is president of the group; Mrs. Gertrude Martin, vice president; Mrs. Lucy Holmes, chairman, and Dr. James B. Cayce, minister."
TitMainTitle: Group portrait of man and ten elderly women, including front row from left: Dolly Johnson, Mattie Davis, Minnie Campbell, Anna Watts, Mrs. Abraham Lincoln, and Anna Craig; back row: Louise Williams, Alice Bollar, James Hughes, Betty Evans, and Cornelia Twyman, posed around park bench in Highland Park for annual "Old Folks" picnic
